Miscellaneous Highlights: All Pirates players and coaches wore No. 21 jerseys as a tribute to Roberto Clemente.
The No. 21 was also cut into grass in right field in front of the Clemente Wall, which is 21 feet high.
Others: Roberto Clemente’s three sons -- Roberto Jr., Luis, and Ricky -- threw out ceremonial first pitches in unison.
Roberto Clemente III and Leo Roberto, the sons of Roberto Jr., shouted 'Play Ball' into an on-field microphone to signify the start of play.
Fans received a collectible Clemente baseball card.
Pitcher David Bednar was recognized during an on-field ceremony.
A player from each of Pittsburgh’s Minor League affiliates and development teams was saluted for outstanding contributions to the community.
Pirates players, coaches, and front office members participated in the team’s annual Roberto Clemente Day of Service.
Volunteers made improvements to three fields at Brighton Heights Park for the Northside RBI program.
Pirates provided food to more than 150 veterans and their families at a drive-thru food distribution center in Pittsburgh’s Strip District.
Players and coaches visited the Allegheny Health Network Exercise Oncology and Resiliency Center to provide instruction to cancer patients.
The Pirates and corporate partner Sheetz prepared lunch for residents and staff at the Women’s Center & Shelter of Greater Pittsburgh.
Pirates visited Pittsburgh’s Latino Community Center to restock the food pantry, assemble snack packs, and provide toys and activities for children affected by food insecurity.
Nearly 150 Pirates front office and corporate partner volunteers, and upwards of 40 players and coaches, took part in the day of service on Friday, giving back to the Pittsburgh community.
